data.title: Error importing XML through MGCB - "The XML element 'item' is required!"
[iOS] Disable "Generate overflow checks"
data.body:
After upgrading to the unified API we started getting overflow exceptions in MonoGame here:
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Content/ContentReaders/Texture2DReader.cs#L195

Here ushort is cast to byte. Disabling "Generate overflow checks" resolves the issue.

We need to stop adding `<CheckForOverflowUnderflow>True</CheckForOverflowUnderflow>` to the debug build configurations.
@hach-que Can you remove it?
https://github.com/hach-que/Protobuild/blob/fea0c15222535b3dac5a536f3d8dbd04bc5d6179/Protobuild.Internal/BuildResources/GenerateProject.CSharp.xslt#L496

`<AllowUnsafeBlocks>True</AllowUnsafeBlocks>` can be removed too because the default value is true and it is a project level toggle, not a configuration level one.

![proj](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/431167/5821349/aa48dd14-a0cb-11e4-87e6-5a031cbf2cbe.png)

data.title: Corrected thumbstick output range for GamePadDeadZone.Circular
data.body: Corrected some overclamping in thumbstick deadzone calculation which added stutter when GamePadDeadZone.Circular is used.

data.title: Multi Game/GraphicsDevice within single process feature
data.body:
this commit resolves #1823
- FEATURE: GraphicsDeviceContext added for backward compatibility with XNA framework
  (Squashed)
- REFACTOR: EffectCache moved from Effect to GraphicsDeviceContext
- REFACTOR: Moved ResetStates in GraphicsDevice to GraphicsDeviceContext
- REFACTOR: Default BlendState are moved to GraphicsDeviceContext
- TASK: Defensive code against usage of GraphicsResource.Current
- FIX: (Windows) Closing game window shouldn't close whole application
- TASK: Build definitions update for GraphicsDeviceContext
- WORKAROUND: Hacks to workaround usage of static member _allWindows in WinFormsGameWindow
- TASK: DebugAssertion for GraphicsDeviceContext added to GraphicsResource
- REFACTOR: Proper disposal of GraphicsResource

data.title: New NUGet package specifications for the automated build
data.body:
Also Removed old MonoGame.NuGetPackager as it has been superseded

New PR for #2843, over to you @tomspilman

data.title: Automated NuGet packaging
data.body:
Includes all the NuSpec definitions required for automated building.
- NuGet.exe added to Tools\NuGet folder.  
  Should run NuGet -update prior to build to ensure it is the latest (verify TeamCity does this) 
- New NuGetPackages folder added
  This contains all the NuSpec files and dependant files needed for packages
- Removed old MonoGame.NuGetpackager system as this is now superseded by the automated NuGet's

data.title: Fixed a number of outstanding issues with the VS 2013 project templates
data.body:
- The Windows Phone project would not create in vs2013 (fix suggested by BrianPeek - https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/3363#issuecomment-69652760)
- Fixed the Universal project definitions to use Executable="$targetnametoken$.exe" and $safeprojectname$ everywhere else, also suggested by Brian
- Added the c builder import, MonoGamePlatform and  MonoGameContentBuilderExe tags to the individual Universal projects (they were missing, meaning Content projects couldn't be added at all)
- Added Content in to the Shared project in the universal build and added linked references in the platform projects.  Tested locally and it works.

Resolves issues identified in #3363

data.title: Opening broken .mgcb files throws exceptions
data.body:
Sorry if this is a duplicate pull request... I didn't see another like it. When opening a broken MGCB file in pipeline.exe I am getting:

```
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object
  at MonoGame.Tools.Pipeline.PipelineController+<OpenProject>c__AnonStorey0.<>m__0 (System.String msg, System.Object[] args) [0x00027] in /home/emarcotte/src/MonoGame/Tools/Pipeline/Common/PipelineController.cs:218 
  at MGCB.MGBuildParser.ShowError (System.String message, System.Object[] args) [0x00020] in /home/emarcotte/src/MonoGame/Tools/MGCB/CommandLineParser.cs:480 
  at MGCB.MGBuildParser.ParseArgument (System.String arg) [0x0008b] in /home/emarcotte/src/MonoGame/Tools/MGCB/CommandLineParser.cs:336 
  at MGCB.MGBuildParser.Parse (IEnumerable`1 args) [0x00027] in /home/emarcotte/src/MonoGame/Tools/MGCB/CommandLineParser.cs:190 
  at MonoGame.Tools.Pipeline.PipelineProjectParser.OpenProject (System.String projectFilePath, MGCB.ErrorCallback errorCallback) [0x00053] in /home/emarcotte/src/MonoGame/Tools/Pipeline/Common/PipelineProjectParser.cs:238 
  at MonoGame.Tools.Pipeline.PipelineController.OpenProject (System.String projectFilePath) [0x0006a] in /home/emarcotte/src/MonoGame/Tools/Pipeline/Common/PipelineController.cs:219 
  at MonoGame.Tools.Pipeline.MainWindow.OnShowEvent () [0x00063] in /home/emarcotte/src/MonoGame/Tools/Pipeline/Gtk/MainWindow.cs:115 
  at MonoGame.Tools.Pipeline.Program.Main (System.String[] args) [0x00045] in /home/emarcotte/src/MonoGame/Tools/Pipeline/Program.cs:53 
```

It seems like the `View` property isn't being set on the `PipelineController` but is required by some other code (I didn't chase down this thread very far). The _view is required by the constructor, and seems to work properly when I switch to using it. I can try to dig down further into removing `View` if it isn't needed.

Here's a sample .mgcb file that caused the error:

```
/outputDir:bin
/intermediateDir:obj
/platform:Linux
/config:AnyCPU
/profile:Reach
/compress:False
/incremental
```

The /incremental is invalid and it crashes trying to read it. This happens both at startup (opening file from history) and just doing file -> open. After this change the error message is displayed in the middle.

data.title: SpriteFont Texture Color are swapped from RGBA to BGRA even if processor is set to Color

data.title: Tests that use Game.RunOneFrame aren't actually executed in XNA
data.body:
A pattern MonoGame uses in some of its tests, specifically the ones in fixtures derived from `VisualTestFixtureBase`, is to register an event handler with `Game.DrawWith`, and then call `Game.RunOneFrame()`. But I noticed while working in `VertexBufferTest.cs` that, when running these tests under XNA, the test window is never shown and the `DrawWith` event handler is never called, and so the test gives a false positive.

Only a few tests use this pattern:
- `IndexBufferTest.cs`
- `Texture2DTest.cs`
- `Texture3DTest.cs`
- `VertexBufferTest.cs`

The simplest fix is to replace these calls to `Game.RunOneFrame()` with `Game.Run()`. This works because the tests use a custom `Game` class, which defines a new `Run` method, which exits the game after some condition evaluates to true. By default, that condition is "exit after drawing one frame". So within the context of these tests, `Game.Run()` does exactly the same thing as `Game.RunOneFrame()`.

If, instead, we want to find the root cause so that we can continue using `RunOneFrame`, then... looking in the debugger immediately after `Game.RunOneFrame()` has been called, I can see that `IsActive`, as well as `doneFirstUpdate`, `doneFirstDraw`, etc. are all `false`. I have tried calling `Initialize` before `RunOneFrame`, but that doesn't help.

I can see in MG's implementation of `RunOneFrame()` that we initialise the game if it hasn't already been initialised. My best guess is that XNA doesn't do this - it expects the game to already be initialised (which it does in `Run`, but apparently not in `RunOneFrame`) . But I don't know enough about the XNA `Game` class to know how to do that initialisation. (Or put another way, I'm not sure how XNA's `RunOneFrame` is intended to be used at all.)

data.title: WinRT MediaLibrary speedup
data.body: The async IO is very slow on WinRT. When parsing the storage folder for music we made two calls: `GetFilesAsync` to get the files and `GetFoldersAsync` to get subfolders to parse. This PR replaces these two calls with a single `GetItemsAsync` call, which makes the MediaLibrary load almost twice as fast.

data.title: Fixed SpriteSortMode.Texture
data.body:
Fixes #3272.
- Added SpriteSortMode test cases to SpriteBatch tests.
- Introduced an internal property to `Texture2D` to use as the comparison key. Because this key is determined by the load order, the tests should stay deterministic, and getting it is an O(1) operation.

data.title: Added Circle
data.body:
I've noticed that MonoGame (and by extension XNA) doesn't have a base Circle class. On the 3D side we have a BoundingBox, BoundingSphere and even a BoundingFrustrum and on the 2D Side we only have a Rectangle. 

I've always found this odd with XNA considering that Circles play an integral role in collision detection within the 2D Space. Not only are they fast to compute, but they can easily handle common situations in games such as rotated sprites. Since MonoGame is an opened source project, I figured I would see if I could get this basic addition added to the MonoGame framework. 

Within this pull request I have written the Circle and Tests pertaining to it. If there are any problems let me know and I'm willing to solve them because I think that a fully featured Circle would be an extremely useful addition to MonoGame

data.title: iOS 8 rotation handling for iPad and when Info.plist is > SupportedOrientations
data.body:
Having another crack of this as I realised I previously didn't correctly read the original issue encountered in #3271 by @Nezz. So there were actually two separate issues:
1. iOS 8 rotation problems when targeting iPad when you allow _both_ landscape/portrait rotations. This was something other people in the discussion of #3271 were encountering and that was what my previous fix was targeting.
2. The original issue @Nezz was describing was the case where you're Info.plist is a superset of those specified in the root view controller's supported orientations. So e.g. Info.plist is portrait/landscape but you want the root view controller to only support landscape orientations. In this instance, the behaviour should be that the app launches in landscape.

So I've appended my original fix for 1. along with another fix for 2. I've tried a number of iPad/iPhone simulated devices targeting iOS 7.1/8.1 so I'm hopeful that this solves the issues.

data.title: Fixes OpenTK warnings
data.body: Fixes a bunch of OpenTK related warnings that were introduced by the support of Xamarin Unified API (#3382). No functionality is altered in this PR.

data.title: D3D compiler dll dependency
data.body:
Hello there,

I recently installed a new Win8.1 dev environment from scratch. After installing VS2013 (which includes Windows SDK 8.1 -- which itself include DirectX SDK ---), I tried to compile a MonoGame project targeting Windows DX.

I stumbled upon an mgcb/pipeline error when building shaders: `Unable to load d3d_compiler_43.dll`

This dll/compiler is present in the discontinued DirectX SDK from June 2010.

Shader compiler are now redistributed with the Windows SDK (the 8.1 SDK packs version 47) since Vista, I believe.

The problem is that mgcb refers to a dll which may not be present on all setup and installing an outdated DirectX SDK may not suit every dev.
Making mgcb to search where the shader compiler is installed may be also tedious since the path is different from every Windows SDK version.

The DirectX SDK EULA and documentation (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ee663275.aspx) states that any project using run-time shader compilation can be redistributed with the proper compiler dll/version. Would it be safe to do so with MonoGame installer? That would remove any dependencies for setting up MonoGame projects targeting Windows.

Let me know if that makes sense and I'll see if can manage to make the change to mgcb and the installer.

data.title: Gtk Pipeline new project improvement
data.body: If gtk filter is set to ".mgcb" while creating a new project it should automatically add it to the end of the filename.

data.title: Allow line break as element separator during deserialization
data.body:
Fixes #3404.

I don't know enough about this code to know whether this is a safe change - @tomspilman, does this look okay to you? I'm not sure what other types of data we might be deserializing, and whether a line break is always an acceptable separator.

data.title: Metro to Modern transformation
data.body:
All classes begins with Metro should be renamed to Modern(without UI) because Microsoft is changed it long time ago - http://www.theverge.com/2012/8/10/3232921/microsoft-modern-ui-style-metro-style-replacement
Also I remove not used references and fix licenses.
